column10: Function
column11: Citation

column10: The PTPN22 gene variant (C1858T) is associated with lower beta-cell function and poorer metabolic control in individuals with type 1 diabetes over a 12-month period, indicating its influence on disease progression.
column11: Petrone, A., Spoletini, M., Zampetti, S., Capizzi, M., Zavarella, S., Osborn, J., Pozzilli, P., Buzzetti, R., & Immunotherapy Diabetes (IMDIAB) Group (2008). The PTPN22 1858T gene variant in type 1 diabetes is associated with reduced residual beta-cell function and worse metabolic control. Diabetes care, 31(6), 1214?1218. https://doi.org/10.2337/dc07-1158

column10: PGM1 gene is implicated in glioma progression by promoting cell viability, glycolysis, and oxidative phosphorylation under low glucose conditions. Higher PGM1 expression in glioma patients correlates with poor survival rates. Knock-down of PGM1 reduces these processes, while overexpression enhances them via a Myc positive feedback loop
column11: Liu, S., Deng, Y., Yu, Y., & Xia, X. (2023). Knock-down of PGM1 inhibits cell viability, glycolysis, and oxidative phosphorylation in glioma under low glucose condition via the Myc signaling pathway. Biochemical and biophysical research communications, 656, 38?45. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bbrc.2023.03.034

column10: The IL6R gene, which encodes the interleukin-6 receptor, is examined for associations with asthma in a Han Chinese population. Certain IL6R gene variants are linked to decreased lung function in asthma patients, with the rs2228145 A-C variant associated with elevated levels of soluble IL-6 receptor and IgE.
column11: Wang, Y., Hu, H., Wu, J., Zhao, X., Zhen, Y., Wang, S., Li, W., Liang, M., Wu, B., & Ma, G. (2016). The IL6R gene polymorphisms are associated with sIL-6R, IgE and lung function in Chinese patients with asthma. Gene, 585(1), 51?57. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gene.2016.03.026

column10: The FASLG gene, which encodes the Fas ligand, is associated with immune response and inflammation. Overexpression of FASLG in older individuals, especially those over 50, may contribute to a hyperinflammatory response. FASLG is expressed in natural killer cells and CD8+ T lymphocytes in SARS-CoV-2-infected patients
column11: de Almeida Chuffa, L. G., Freire, P. P., Dos Santos Souza, J., de Mello, M. C., de Oliveira Neto, M., & Carvalho, R. F. (2022). Aging whole blood transcriptome reveals candidate genes for SARS-CoV-2-related vascular and immune alterations. Journal of molecular medicine (Berlin, Germany), 100(2), 285?301. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00109-021-02161-4

column10: GRHL3, essential for skin repair and development, is identified as a potential target gene for skin-related disorders, linking to a risk variant previously associated with IFNLR1.
column11: Shi, C., Ray-Jones, H., Ding, J., Duffus, K., Fu, Y., Gaddi, V. P., Gough, O., Hankinson, J., Martin, P., McGovern, A., Yarwood, A., Gaffney, P., Eyre, S., Rattray, M., Warren, R. B., & Orozco, G. (2021). Chromatin Looping Links Target Genes with Genetic Risk Loci for Dermatological Traits. The Journal of investigative dermatology, 141(8), 1975?1984. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jid.2021.01.015

column10: The FAIM2 gene, located within the ch12q13 obesity locus, contains the rs7132908 variant, which has been validated as a causal obesity variant. This variant affects disease susceptibility through cis-regulation, impacting FAIM2 expression and influencing neurodevelopment and cell survival during differentiation into hypothalamic neurons.
column11: Littleton, S. H., Trang, K. B., Volpe, C. M., Cook, K., DeBruyne, N., Ann Maguire, J., Ann Weidekamp, M., Boehm, K., Chesi, A., Pippin, J. A., Anderson, S. A., Wells, A. D., Pahl, M. C., & Grant, S. F. A. (2023). Variant-to-function analysis of the childhood obesity chr12q13 locus implicates rs7132908 as a causal variant within the 3' UTR of FAIM2. bioRxiv : the preprint server for biology, 2023.08.21.553157. https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.08.21.553157

column10: Filaggrin gene defects increase the risk of allergic sensitisation, atopic eczema, allergic rhinitis, and asthma, particularly in individuals with atopic eczema. Restoring skin barrier function in individuals with filaggrin deficiencies may help prevent the development and progression of allergic disease.
column11: van den Oord, R. A., & Sheikh, A. (2009). Filaggrin gene defects and risk of developing allergic sensitisation and allergic disorders: systematic review and meta-analysis. BMJ (Clinical research ed.), 339, b2433. https://doi.org/10.1136/bmj.b2433

column10: The IFIH1 gene codes for MDA5, a sensor detecting viral RNA. Variants in IFIH1 impair MDA5 function, leading to compromised viral sensing in the gut and contributing to Very Early Onset Inflammatory Bowel Disease (VEOIBD).
column11: Cananzi, M., Wohler, E., Marzollo, A., Colavito, D., You, J., Jing, H., Bresolin, S., Gaio, P., Martin, R., Mescoli, C., Bade, S., Posey, J. E., Dalle Carbonare, M., Tung, W., Jhangiani, S. N., Bosa, L., Zhang, Y., Filho, J. S., Gabelli, M., Kellermayer, R., ? Guerrerio, A. L. (2021). IFIH1 loss-of-function variants contribute to very early-onset inflammatory bowel disease. Human genetics, 140(9), 1299?1312. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00439-021-02300-4

column10: IFIH1 gene encodes a protein involved in the innate immune response by sensing viral RNA. Variants in IFIH1 are associated with type 1 diabetes susceptibility, impacting autoimmune processes and beta-cell fragility.
column11: Shapiro, M. R., Thirawatananond, P., Peters, L., Sharp, R. C., Ogundare, S., Posgai, A. L., Perry, D. J., & Brusko, T. M. (2021). De-coding genetic risk variants in type 1 diabetes. Immunology and cell biology, 99(5), 496?508. https://doi.org/10.1111/imcb.12438

column10: The IFIH1 gene encodes for MDA5, a sensor responsible for detecting viral nucleic acids. In this study, upregulation of IFIH1 was identified as a hub gene associated with nut allergy. This suggests a potential role for MDA5-mediated immune responses, particularly type 1 interferon signaling, in the pathogenesis of nut allergy.
column11: Lee, K. H., Bosco, A., O'Sullivan, M., Song, Y., Metcalfe, J., Yu, K., Mullins, B. J., Loh, R., & Zhang, G. (2022). Identifying gene network patterns and associated cellular immune responses in children with or without nut allergy. The World Allergy Organization journal, 15(2), 100631. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.waojou.2022.100631

column10: The STAT4 gene variant rs7574865 was investigated in relation to type 1 diabetes (T1D) susceptibility in Egyptians. The study found a significant correlation between the T allele and GT genotype of rs7574865 and T1D incidence. This suggests that genetic variations in STAT4 may contribute to T1D development by influencing immune responses involved in pancreatic cell destruction.
column11: Abdelmajed, S. S., El-Dessouky, M. A., SalahElDin, D. S., Hassan, N. A., Zaki, M. E., & Ismail, S. (2021). Assessing the association of rs7574865 STAT4 gene variant and type 1 diabetes mellitus among Egyptian patients. Journal, genetic engineering & biotechnology, 19(1), 112. https://doi.org/10.1186/s43141-021-00214-2

column10: The STAT4 gene is essential for rapid effector responses of natural killer (NK) cells and type 1 innate lymphoid cells (ILC1) against pathogens. Deletion of Stat4 impairs NK cell differentiation and leads to increased cytotoxic ILC1 generation during intestinal inflammation. Mechanistically, Stat4-deficient I1LC1 show upregulated gene modules regulated by STAT5, resulting in abe1rrant differentiation. Moreover, STAT4 expression in innate lymphocytes restrains gut inflammation by limiting pathogenic IL-13 production from adaptive CD4+ T cells.
column11: Scarno, G., Mazej, J., Laffranchi, M., Di Censo, C., Mattiola, I., Candelotti, A. M., Pietropaolo, G., Stabile, H., Fionda, C., Peruzzi, G., Brooks, S. R., Tsai, W. L., Mikami, Y., Bernardini, G., Gismondi, A., Sozzani, S., Di Santo, J. P., Vosshenrich, C. A. J., Diefenbach, A., Gadina, M., ? Sciumä, G. (2023). Divergent roles for STAT4 in shaping differentiation of cytotoxic ILC1 and NK cells during gut inflammation. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America, 120(40), e2306761120. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2306761120

column10: The CTLA4 gene encodes a protein that regulates immune responses. Variants in CTLA4 are associated with type 1 diabetes risk, as they may disrupt immune regulation and contribute to autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells. Understanding CTLA4's role in immune function provides insight into type 1 diabetes mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets.
column11: Redondo, M. J., Onengut-Gumuscu, S., & Gaulton, K. J. (2023). Genetics of Type 1 Diabetes. In J. M. Lawrence (Eds.) et. al., Diabetes in America. National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK).

column10: The CTLA4 gene encodes a protein that regulates immune responses. Variants in CTLA4 are associated with type 1 diabetes risk, as they may disrupt immune regulation and contribute to autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells. Understanding CTLA4's role in immune function provides insight into type 1 diabetes mechanisms and potential therapeutic targets.
column11: Redondo, M. J., Onengut-Gumuscu, S., & Gaulton, K. J. (2023). Genetics of Type 1 Diabetes. In J. M. Lawrence (Eds.) et. al., Diabetes in America. National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK).

column10: SKAP1 gene is implicated in the regulation of gene expression, particularly in relation to peanut allergy (PA) and food allergy. SKAP1 regulates the expression of CBX1, which colocalizes with the EMSY protein coded by C11orf30. This implies that SKAP1 may play a role in epigenetic regulation, specifically in the context of gene expression associated with PA and food allergy.
column11: Asai, Y., Eslami, A., van Ginkel, C. D., Akhabir, L., Wan, M., Ellis, G., Ben-Shoshan, M., Martino, D., Ferreira, M. A., Allen, K., Mazer, B., de Groot, H., de Jong, N. W., Gerth van Wijk, R. N., Dubois, A. E. J., Chin, R., Cheuk, S., Hoffman, J., Jorgensen, E., Witte, J. S., ? Daley, D. (2018). Genome-wide association study and meta-analysis in multiple populations identifies new loci for peanut allergy and establishes C11orf30/EMSY as a genetic risk factor for food allergy. The Journal of allergy and clinical immunology, 141(3), 991?1001. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jaci.2017.09.015

column10: CTNNA3 gene is implicated in the susceptibility to toluene diisocyanate (TDI)-induced asthma. Specifically, genetic polymorphisms of CTNNA3 are significantly associated with the TDI-induced asthma phenotype. Carriers of specific haplotypes of CTNNA3 genetic polymorphisms show lower methacholine sensitivity and reduced mRNA expression of CTNNA3.
column11: Kim, S. H., Cho, B. Y., Park, C. S., Shin, E. S., Cho, E. Y., Yang, E. M., Kim, C. W., Hong, C. S., Lee, J. E., & Park, H. S. (2009). Alpha-T-catenin (CTNNA3) gene was identified as a risk variant for toluene diisocyanate-induced asthma by genome-wide association analysis. Clinical and experimental allergy : journal of the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology, 39(2), 203?212. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2222.2008.03117.x

column10: IL10RA gene encodes for the interleukin-10 receptor alpha chain, which is a crucial component of the interleukin-10 (IL-10) receptor complex. IL-10RA is responsible for mediating the biological effects of IL-10, a cytokine with anti-inflammatory properties. When IL-10 binds to its receptor, the IL-10RA chain initiates downstream signaling pathways that regulate immune responses and inflammation.
column11: Maculewicz, E., Dzitkowska-Zabielska, M., Antkowiak, B., Antkowiak, O., Mastalerz, A., Garbacz, A., Massidda, M., Bojarczuk, A., Dziuda, ?., & Ci?szczyk, P. (2022). Association of Interleukin Genes IL10 and IL10RB with Parameters of Overweight in Military Students. Genes, 13(2), 291. https://doi.org/10.3390/genes13020291

column10: RBPJ gene, involved in the Notch signaling pathway, likely plays a role in promoting insulin-producing cell formation from pancreatic progenitor cells. Knockdown experiments suggest that RBPJ facilitates this process, highlighting its importance in pancreatic development and potential diabetes therapies.
column11: Bai, C., Li, X., Gao, Y., Wang, K., Fan, Y., Zhang, S., Ma, Y., & Guan, W. (2016). Role of microRNA-21 in the formation of insulin-producing cells from pancreatic progenitor cells. Biochimica et biophysica acta, 1859(2), 280?293. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bbagrm.2015.12.001

column10: IL-10 gene is described as repressing proinflammatory responses and limiting unnecessary tissue disruptions caused by inflammation. Additionally, it mentions that IL-10 family cytokines, including IL-10 itself, elicit diverse host defense mechanisms, especially from epithelial cells, during various infections, and are essential for maintaining tissue integrity and homeostasis.
column11: Ouyang, W., Rutz, S., Crellin, N. K., Valdez, P. A., & Hymowitz, S. G. (2011). Regulation and functions of the IL-10 family of cytokines in inflammation and disease. Annual review of immunology, 29, 71?109. https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-immunol-031210-101312

column10: The IL13 gene is crucial in initiating IgE class switching in B cells and is highly relevant in the context of food allergy research. Specific genetic variants, like rs1295686, have been linked to an increased risk of challenge-proven IgE-mediated food allergy, as well as elevated total plasma IgE levels.
column11: Ashley, S. E., Tan, H. T., Peters, R., Allen, K. J., Vuillermin, P., Dharmage, S. C., Tang, M. L. K., Koplin, J., Lowe, A., Ponsonby, A. L., Molloy, J., Matheson, M. C., Saffery, R., Ellis, J. A., Martino, D., & HealthNuts team (2017). Genetic variation at the Th2 immune gene IL13 is associated with IgE-mediated paediatric food allergy. Clinical and experimental allergy : journal of the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology, 47(8), 1032?1037. https://doi.org/10.1111/cea.12942

column10: The TGFBR1 gene encodes a receptor for TGF?. Mutations in TGFBR1 contribute to allergic diseases like asthma and eczema in patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome by altering TGF? signaling, leading to immune dysregulation and TH2 cytokine production.
column11: Frischmeyer-Guerrerio, P. A., Guerrerio, A. L., Oswald, G., Chichester, K., Myers, L., Halushka, M. K., Oliva-Hemker, M., Wood, R. A., & Dietz, H. C. (2013). TGF? receptor mutations impose a strong predisposition for human allergic disease. Science translational medicine, 5(195), 195ra94. https://doi.org/10.1126/scitranslmed.3006448

column10: The NRP1 gene is implicated in diabetic kidney disease (DKD) progression. It promotes endothelium-mesenchymal transition in glomerular endothelial cells through interaction with semaphorin 3C (SEMA3C). Higher levels of urinary SEMA3C/Cr are positively correlated with glomerular injury, highlighting NRP1's role in DKD pathophysiology.
column11: Tsai, Y. C., Kuo, M. C., Huang, J. C., Chang, W. A., Wu, L. Y., Huang, Y. C., Chang, C. Y., Lee, S. C., & Hsu, Y. L. (2023). Single-cell transcriptomic profiles in the pathophysiology within the microenvironment of early diabetic kidney disease. Cell death & disease, 14(7), 442. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41419-023-05947-1

column10: The RNLS gene, discovered through a genome-scale CRISPR screen, plays a role in type 1 diabetes progression. Deleting RNLS made beta cells resistant to autoimmune destruction, suggesting it as a potential therapeutic target for preventing beta cell loss in T1D.
column11: Cai, E. P., Ishikawa, Y., Zhang, W., Leite, N. C., Li, J., Hou, S., Kiaf, B., Hollister-Lock, J., Yilmaz, N. K., Schiffer, C. A., Melton, D. A., Kissler, S., & Yi, P. (2020). Genome-scale in vivo CRISPR screen identifies RNLS as a target for beta cell protection in type 1 diabetes. Nature metabolism, 2(9), 934?945. https://doi.org/10.1038/s42255-020-0254-1
